Evergy has completed this report to provide the public with information about our activities at this facility.  We believe that, due to the many controls instituted to maintain a safe operation and our commitment to continuous improvement, an incident affecting our employees or the surrounding area is unlikely to occur.

Hot Work Permit [40 CFR Part 68.85]
Evergy has a hot work permit that requires issuance of a hot work permit for hot work operations conducted on or near the covered process.

Contractors [40 CFR Part 68.87] 
Evergy hires contractors to conduct specialty maintenance activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance is carried out. Evergy has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards associated with the contractor's work and the corresponding processes. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response in the event of an accidental release of a regulated substance.
The five-year accident history [40 CFR 68.155(d)]:
The Hawthorn Generating Station has had no ammonia releases in the past five years which need to be reported in the five-year accident history.
The emergency response program [40 CFR 68.155(e)]:
Plant personnel are trained to respond to incidental leaks that can be managed by shutting off key emergency valves. Outside contractors are on call to make any repairs needed to the ammonia system.  Any response requiring entry into a dangerous atmosphere or situation will be performed by the Kansas City Fire Department (KCFD). Ammonia response procedures are discussed during the annual inspection by the KCFD. A copy of the Hawthorn Station's modified Emergency Action Plan is included.  Employees are provided emergency response awareness training annually.

The Plant Environmental Compliance Coordinator attends the monthly meetings of the Mid-America Regional Committee (MARC) LEPC to maintain a close relationship with all regional emergency response personnel. Management of Change [MOC] [40 CFR Part 68.75]
Written procedures are in place at Evergy to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures. Facility operators or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification(s).

Pre-Startup Safety Review [PSSR] [40 CFR Part 68.77]
Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and modifications to existing processes are conducted routinely at Evergy. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating, and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits [40 CFR Part 68.79]
Evergy conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the US EPA RMP and OSHA PSM regulations are being implemented. These audits are conducted at least every 3 years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a prompt manner.

Incident Investigation [40 CFR Part 68.81]
Evergy promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum period of 5 years.

Employee Participation [40 CFR Part 68.83]

The most recent process hazard analysis was performed using a 'What If?' type analysis for the Unit #5 and Unit 9 ammonia systems.  During the PHAs, each system was methodically assessed and evaluated. Points in the system where ammonia could potentially be released were identified.  Valves that are relied upon to respond to an ammonia release were identified as shown on the system engineering diagrams. Comments and recommendations are summarized in the Process Hazard Analysis section of the Risk Management Program and are resolved in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures [40 CFR Part 68.69]
To ensure safe operations, Evergy maintains detailed written operating procedures. Standard operating procedures (SOPs) for startup, shutdown, normal operation and emergency operation of both ammonia storage systems are in place. The SOPs are posted in appropriate areas. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the process.

Training [40 CFR Part 68.71]
Personnel are trained annually on safety concerns and general operation procedures as well as emergency procedures. Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.

Mechanical Integrity [40 CFR Part 68.73]
The ammonia systems is visually inspected once per shift on a 24-hour per day basis. Plant security personnel inspect the areas in which the ammonia tanks are located on an hourly basis.  The Hawthorn Generating Station has established operation, maintenance and inspection procedures for the anhydrous ammonia system. There are Operation and Maintenance manuals for each major piece of equipment, and personnel will receive training before being allowed to work on the systems. The larger ammonia tank at Unit #5 is equipped with a water sprinkler system on the exterior of the tank to cool the tank and piping. Consequence Analysis Guidance.

This type of rapid release would occur only if the ammonia tanks were breached. The likelihood of such an incident occurring is miniscule; anhydrous ammonia tanks are installed with multiple safety systems to prevent the release of an entire tank in a single event.

Alternative Release Scenario
The alternative release scenario is, by definition, a more likely release scenario than the worst case. Engineered controls, such as automatic shut-off valves, check valves, relief valves and water misting system can be considered in the analysis.

The type of system failure identified for the alternative release was a loss of ammonia caused by a major leak in the liquid piping network between the tank and vaporizers. As a conservative estimate, the rate of release was assumed to be the maximum flow that would not cause the ammonia storage tank liquid excess flow valves to automatically shut. The leak was assumed to continue until the ammonia odor would alert an operator or plant security personnel. The main isolation valve would be closed manually if it is safe to do so. If the ammonia vapor concentration is unsafe for facility response, the Kansas City Fire Department will be called to respond to the emergency. The estimated time for leak detection and complete response for the Fire Department in the alternate release scenario is 60 minutes.

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps [40 CFR 68.155(c)]:
Evergy has a program in place to comply with the provisions of the accidental release prevention regulations under 40 CFR Part 68. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the existing release prevention program.

Process Safety Information [40 CFR Part 68.65]
Evergy Hawthorn maintains a detailed record of process safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with the ammonia processes.

The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source [40 CFR 68.155(a)]:
The Hawthorn Generating Station is located in Jackson County, Missouri, at 8700 East Front Street, Kansas City. The facility is situated east of Interstate I-435 on the south bank of the Missouri River, west of the confluence of the Missouri and Blue Rivers. The property south and west of the Hawthorn Generating Station is urban and occupied by other industrial entities. The strip of property directly across the Missouri River from the Hawthorn Generating Station is generally not developed and wooded.

Anhydrous ammonia is used at the Hawthorn Generating Station as an air pollution control additive, to reduce the nitrogen oxide (NOx) emissions to the atmosphere from the unit boilers. Each boiler unit is equipped with a selective catalytic reduction (SCR) device.
The stationary source and regulated substances handled [40 CFR 68.155(b)]:
Evergy Hawthorn Generating Station maintains one substance, anhydrous ammonia, on site in amounts exceeding the Risk Management Program (RMP) threshold quantities. The listed RMP rule threshold quantity is 10,000 pounds. Evergy stores the chemical in one (1) 8,000 gallon (39,000 pounds) tank and one (1) 30,000 gallon (145,000 pounds) tank. The storage and management of anhydrous ammonia for both systems is addressed in this Risk Management Plan (RMPlan).

The Worst Case Release Scenario
The worst case release scenario for ammonia was calculated as the loss of the larger 30,000-gallon tank in accordance with the definition provided in the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) guidance for RMP development. The ammonia would be released as a gas. As required by the rule, only administrative control systems such as the company policy to fill the tanks to a maximum of 85% liquid by volume, were taken into consideration.
